comment.author: 97381978@N00
comment._content: I believe this vessel can be tentatively identified as HMS Torch one of only two vessels of the Alert Class of steel screw sloops and the first to be fitted with quick firing guns as opposed to the earlier breech loading type. The guns were four-inch Mark III type. My reasons for this identification are: 1) a three-gun broadside mounted high, low, high as we see in the photo. The first and third guns are on the same deck level, number two gun is a deck below. Only the Alert Class (Alert and Torch) were so armed in the Royal Navy. 2) the single funnel and absence of copper sheathing. HMS Torch was single funnelled and steel sheathed. The vessel above appears steel sheathed. 3) probably British as shown by the crew's uniforms. The only vessel which seems to fit is HMS Torch as her sister ship HMS Alert served on other stations. HMS Torch was in Australian and New Zealand waters from 1897 onwards: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alert_class_sloop#HMS_Torch You will note that the Wikipedia photo shows her still rigged around 1900 while the above photo shows no spars. I suspect the absence of spars on the masts is merely because she is in dry dock. The Victorian livery marks this as 1903/1904 or earlier. I would guess that this is HMS Torch probably undergoing refit upon her arrival on the Australian station. Please add to: Naval History
